Hero.welcomeTitle: Uniting our differences to transform the world.
Hero.welcomeDescription: We draw inspiration from the teachings of the Bahá'í Faith, whose fundamental purpose is to "promote the unity of the human race, and to foster the spirit of love and fellowship amongst men."

HomePageContent.communitySectionTitle: A welcoming community at the heart of Montreal
HomePageContent.communitySectionDescription: Alongside their friends and neighbours, the Bahá'ís of Montreal strive to build vibrant communities by strengthening their capacity to serve others and by fostering deep and genuine friendships with all those around them, grounded in mutual support and collaboration.
HomePageContent.activitiesSectionTitle: Working together to build vibrant communities
HomePageContent.activitiesSectionDescription: The Bahá'í community actively participates in a range of initiatives, animated by a deep commitment to fostering unity among all peoples.
HomePageContent.activityBox1Description: In homes across Montreal, Bahá'ís gather with friends and families to reflect, pray, and meditate together. These gatherings are shaped by the participants themselves, and adapted to the circumstances of each group.
HomePageContent.activityBox2Description: Alongside people of all beliefs, Bahá'ís gather to explore together the spiritual teachings found in the sacred Writings. They reflect collectively on their deeper meanings and how these teachings can illuminate their daily lives. These spaces often integrate the arts as well as scientific perspectives, allowing for a more holistic approach that nourishes the intellect, the heart, and the spirit. These spaces serve a dual purpose: to foster the inner transformation of each person and to contribute to the betterment of society.
HomePageContent.activityBox3Description: The Bahá'í community places great importance on the spiritual, moral, and intellectual development of children and junior youth, enabling them to cultivate the capacities needed to contribute to their communities and to grow as individuals.
HomePageContent.activityBox4Description: The involvement of Bahá'ís in social action is increasingly expressed through partnerships with community organizations, academic support activities, and a range of service projects within neighbourhoods across Montreal.
HomePageContent.unityDiversityDescription1: The fundamental aim of the Bahá'í teachings is to promote the unity of the human race and to foster a spirit of love and fellowship among all the peoples of the earth.
HomePageContent.unityDiversityDescription2: This unity does not seek to impose uniformity, but rather to celebrate human diversity. It invites every culture, every tradition, and every individual to offer their unique contribution to the great mosaic of humanity.
HomePageContent.unityDiversityQuote: If religion becomes a cause of dislike, hatred and division, it were better to be without it, and to withdraw from such a religion would be a truly religious act [...] Any religion which is not a cause of love and unity is no religion.
HomePageContent.unityDiversityButton: Learn more about the Bahá'í teachings
HomePageContent.sanctuaryDescription: The Bahá'í Shrine in Montreal welcomes visitors who wish to discover this site of spiritual and historic significance. Guided visits are available by appointment.

VisionPage.title: What We Believe
VisionPage.transcendentGodTitle: God is transcendent and beyond human conception
VisionPage.transcendentGodText: For Bahá'ís, God is the creative source of all existence. This divine Reality, imperceptible and invisible, transcends human intelligence and understanding: It encompasses all things and therefore cannot itself be encompassed. Any conception we may have of the Divine is limited by our material existence. The qualities we attribute to God help us shape our understanding of Reality, but the true nature of this Supreme Essence is unknowable.
VisionPage.progressiveRevelationText1: This conception of the divine explains why different traditions have developed various names and understandings of one same divine Reality: God, Allah, Yahweh, the Tao, the Manitou, the Heavenly Father, and so on. From this perspective, the different religions are not contradictory constructions, but rather responses adapted to the specific needs of the societies that received them. Abraham, Krishna, Zoroaster, Moses, Buddha, Jesus, Muhammad, and more recently Bahá'u'lláh, the Founder of the Bahá'í Faith, are regarded, among others, as Messengers emanating from the same divine Source, each bringing spiritual teachings suited to the time and context in which they appear.
VisionPage.progressiveRevelationText2: Each Revelation builds upon the one before it, conveying a message that is unified in its fundamental truth. Thus, Bahá'ís believe that there is fundamentally only one religion and that successive religious revelations lay, one after another, the spiritual foundations for the continuous progress of civilization.
VisionPage.quoteText: The diversity in the human family should be the cause of love and harmony, as it is in music where many different notes blend together in the making of a perfect chord.
VisionPage.principlesTitle: Essential principles of the Bahá'í Faith
VisionPage.principle1Text: The independent investigation of truth is a central principle of the Bahá'í Faith, and a protection from the blind acceptance of dogma. Each individual is encouraged to seek, question, and discover for themselves. All forms of proselytism are prohibited.
VisionPage.principle2Title: The harmony between science and religion
VisionPage.principle2Text: The harmony between science and religion affirms that these two systems of knowledge, far from being in conflict, complement one another.
VisionPage.principle3Text: The equality of women and men is a fundamental spiritual principle essential to the progress of humanity
VisionPage.principle4Text: Universal education for all, without discrimination, is regarded as a moral and social duty.
VisionPage.principle5Title: Elimination of the extremes of wealth and poverty
VisionPage.principle5Text: The elimination of extremes of wealth and poverty is sought through the establishment of more equitable systems. The spiritual and moral progress of society as a whole is also essential, since material transformation and the elevation of human consciousness are inseparable in the pursuit of true social justice.

ChampsActionPage.title: What we do
ChampsActionPage.quoteText: We cannot segregate the human heart from the environment outside us and say that once one of these is reformed everything will be improved. Man is organic with the world. His inner life moulds the environment and is itself also deeply affected by it. The one acts upon the other and every abiding change in the life of man is the result of these mutual reactions.
ChampsActionPage.introText1: With a deep commitment to fostering unity among all living beings, the Bahá'í community takes part in a range of initiatives, including engagement in social discourses on gender equality, interfaith dialogue, the process of reconciliation with Indigenous peoples, environmental protection, as well as support for families through educational programs for children, adolescents, and adults.

NewsPage.title: Stories
NewsPage.fallbackTitle1: Tribute to Freedom: A concert presented in Montreal in honour of the global struggle for gender equality
NewsPage.fallbackDescription1: An exceptional cultural event brought the Montreal community together to celebrate gender equality through music and the arts. This memorable evening highlighted the importance of unity and mutual respect in building a more just society.
NewsPage.fallbackTitle2: Community service day: Young Bahá'ís mobilized to beautify Montreal parks
NewsPage.fallbackDescription2: More than 50 young people gathered for a day dedicated to community service. Through cleanup activities, tree planting, and environmental awareness, they demonstrated their commitment to the well-being of their city.

SanctuaryPage.title: Bahá'í Shrine in Montreal
SanctuaryPage.historicHomeText1: 'Abdu'l-Bahá, the son of the Founder of the Bahá'í Faith, Bahá'u'lláh, stayed in the home of May and William Sutherland Maxwell during His ten-day visit to Montreal in 1912. Today, this house is cherished as the only Bahá'í Shrine in Canada, honoured for its connection to the visit of 'Abdú'l-Bahá.
SanctuaryPage.historicHomeText2: 'Abdu'l-Bahá referred to the Maxwell residence as His home. During His time in Montreal, He spent four days at the Maxwell house and delivered three public talks. His visit was widely covered in both English and French newspapers, which published dozens of articles highlighting themes of peace, the oneness of religion, freedom from prejudice, and economic inequality.
SanctuaryPage.quoteText: I have sown the seed, You must water it. You must educate the souls in divine morals, make them spiritual and lead them to the oneness of humanity and to universal peace.
SanctuaryPage.planVisitDescription: The Shrine is a haven of peace, open to all, whether for prayer, meditation, or simply to discover the history of this unique place.

FAQPage.title: Learn More
FAQPage.faq1Question: What is the demographic makeup of the Bahá'í community of Montreal?
FAQPage.faq1Answer: The community is as diverse as the population of Montreal itself, both in terms of age and ethnic background. You will find Bahá'ís with cultural roots in many parts of the world. As the religion originated in Persia, there is a particularly large number of Bahá'ís of Iranian origin. The ongoing persecution of Bahá'ís by the Iranian government has led many believers to resettle around the world, including here in Montreal.
FAQPage.faq2Question: How many Bahá'ís are there in Montreal, in Canada, and around the world?
FAQPage.faq2Answer: The Bahá'í Faith has more than five million members worldwide. It is established in over 100,000 localities, in virtually every country and territory of the world. In Canada, there are more than 30,000 members from diverse backgrounds living in over 1,200 localities. In Montreal specifically, there are approximately 400 Bahá'ís.
FAQPage.faq3Question: Who leads the Bahá'í community of Montreal?
FAQPage.faq3Answer: The Bahá'í Faith has no clergy. This means that no intermediary stands between an individual and their spiritual search. Community decisions are made collectively through consultation. The Faith does, however, have an administrative system at the international, national, and local levels. As in most cities around the world, Montreal has its own local administrative council. Known as the Local Spiritual Assembly, this institution is made up of nine members who are elected each year in a non-partisan manner by the Bahá'ís of the city.
FAQPage.faq4Question: Is there a church in Montreal?
FAQPage.faq4Answer: There is no church in the Bahá'í Faith. Activities are mainly organized at the neighbourhood level and take place in informal settings such as homes, parks, or community centres. It is not uncommon to attend a gathering in someone's home, take part in a youth group at a community centre, or have a meaningful conversation in a café. Although there is no church, the Bahá'í Faith does have temples (called "Houses of Worship") that are open to all for prayer and meditation. The House of Worship closest to Montreal is located in Wilmette, Illinois, near Chicago.
FAQPage.faq5Question: How does one become a Bahá'í?
FAQPage.faq5Answer: To be a Bahá'í simply means to recognize Bahá'u'lláh as the Messenger of God for our time and to strive to follow His laws and teachings. There is no formal process or ritual required to become a Bahá'í. If you recognize Bahá'u'lláh and seek to live according to His teachings, then you are a Bahá'í. That said, people generally inform the local administrative council (called the Local Spiritual Assembly) of their faith, so that they can participate fully in community activities and take part in the administrative life of the community.
FAQPage.faq6Question: How can I take part in activities in Montreal?
FAQPage.faq6Answer: Activities take place throughout the city. If you know a Bahá'í in your neighbourhood, you can ask them for more information. Otherwise, you can contact the Local Spiritual Assembly, which can put you in touch with a Bahá'í near you.
FAQPage.faq7Question: What is the connection between Montreal and the history of the Bahá'í Faith?
FAQPage.faq7Answer: Montreal holds a unique place in Bahá'í history. It is the only city in Canada visited by 'Abdu'l-Bahá, the son of Bahá'u'lláh, during His journey to North America in 1912. His visit and stay at the Bahá'í Shrine of Montreal make it a sacred and historically significant place.
FAQPage.faq8Question: Which languages are used in Bahá'í activities in Montreal?
FAQPage.faq8Answer: Bahá'í activities in Montreal are conducted mainly in French and English. Many gatherings are bilingual, and the community strives to be linguistically inclusive, reflecting the city's diversity.
